body.p: It has been six decades since Professor Patricia Jevons first identified a methicillin-resistant strain of Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Since then, our understanding of MRSA's pathogenicity and virulence has expanded significantly and has been accompanied by advances in diagnostics and treatment options. Yet, as the articles in this special edition demonstrate, MRSA remains a significant global public health concern.

MRSA is widely regarded as the “original superbug”, and over the years it has continued to evolve. Toxin producing strains and resistance to additional classes of antibiotics present further challenges. Although other superbugs have emerged, MRSA remains a significant burden. A systematic review by Murray et al. identified MRSA as the pathogen-drug combination responsible for the highest attributable death rate globally [1]. MRSA remains a leading cause of nosocomial infections in healthcare settings. The papers in this special edition, spanning four continents, highlight the persistent threat of MRSA internationally and the challenges imposed by differing resource limitations in its detection and management.

High quality, up-to-date data on the prevalence of multi-drug resistant organisms (MDROs) is often limited in low-income settings. Abebe et al. attempt to address this gap by detailing MRSA colonisation rates among a subset of Ethiopian patients with wound infections [2]. Similarly, Sagiraju et al. investigated MRSA colonisation rates in their diabetic population, finding nearly double the prevalence compared to non-diabetic individuals [3]. Both studies also report significant rates of vancomycin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA). Vancomycin remains a standard treatment for MRSA, but in regions where VRSA is prevalent, the lack of access to microbiological testing to guide treatment poses significant risks to patient outcomes. Fortunately, as antimicrobial resistance has progressed, our treatment options for Gram-positive organisms have expanded – ranging from vancomycin to linezolid, daptomycin, and most recently, dalbavancin. These newer agents have significantly enhanced our treatment arsenal for MRSA in high-income settings, offering advantages such as linezolid's oral formulation and dalbavancin's extended half life, while also eliminating the need for therapeutic drug monitoring. Studies consistently demonstrate that these agents are as effective as vancomycin in treating MRSA [[4], [5], [6], [7]].

Exposure to healthcare settings is a well-recognised risk factor for MRSA colonisation, disproportionately impacting the most vulnerable patient groups. Sigakis et al. reviewed seven years of data, demonstrating that patients colonised with MRSA experience higher mortality rates compared to their MRSA-negative counterparts [8]. Numerous studies have highlighted the association between MRSA colonisation and poorer outcomes across a wide range of specialties [[9], [10], [11]].

Advances in technology have facilitated the rapid detection of MRSA isolates, the identification of toxin-producing strains, and enhanced the management of outbreaks. For instance, MRSA strains producing virulence factors like Panton-Valentine Leucocidin (PVL) present additional challenges in managing cases and outbreaks in the healthcare setting. However, as these studies highlight, access to such technology remains limited in many regions, highlighting global disparities in MRSA management.

Traynor et al. describe a protracted 16-month outbreak of PVL-positive MRSA in a National Burns Unit [12]. Outbreaks of PVL-positive MRSA have also been reported in other high-risk settings, including maternity and neonatal units [13,14]. Traynor et al. highlight the important role that whole genome sequencing (WGS) played in bringing this outbreak to a conclusion. Advances in sequencing technology have transformed MRSA outbreak management by enabling precise discrimination between isolates and improving our ability to trace transmission pathways. In the absence of genomic tools, there is often a reliance on antibiograms for strain differentiation. Yet, as shown by Cerezo et al., this approach can lead to inaccurate conclusions, and in turn complicate outbreak investigations even further [15].

A recurring theme across the eight papers is the emphasis on screening high-risk patients, such as those in critical care units. However, there is no universally adopted guideline on screening and decolonisation protocols. The lack of international consensus on MRSA screening practices may stem from insufficient scientific evidence regarding the clinical utility and cost-effectiveness of different policies, whether targeted or universal [[16], [17], [18]]. Brady et al. describe a prolonged MRSA outbreak in their cardiothoracic high-dependency unit. Despite national guidelines in Ireland not recommending routine screening of healthcare workers, it was implemented in this case, ultimately revealing that the outbreak was linked to a staff member who was subsequently recolonised [19]. Advances in diagnostic capabilities now allow for point of care testing (POCT) for MRSA, offering real-time results as an alternative to traditional culture methods. This rapid turnaround time is particularly valuable when results influence isolation precautions and pre-operative antibiotic prophylaxis regimes. However, it's imperative to recognise that its availability depends on local resources, underscoring the inequalities in MRSA management worldwide.

Healthcare settings face daily challenges from competing infection prevention and control (IPC) demands. As new MDROs have emerged, the prioritisation of MRSA-specific measures has declined in some settings. These challenges have been compounded by pressures from infectious diseases like COVID-19 and Mpox alongside a resurgence of vaccine-preventable diseases such as pertussis and measles. Due to the highly communicable nature of these diseases, they take precedence when it comes to IPC efforts. This is also often in the context of healthcare facilities that lack sufficient isolation resources to meet the growing demands of effective infection control.

In 2021, the Healthcare Infection Society and Infection Prevention Society published joint guidelines for the prevention and control of MRSA in healthcare facilities [20]. These guidelines offer a pragmatic approach and acknowledge the variations in local resources and policies that exist. Acknowledging that screening, isolation and IPC measures are not universally accessible, the guidelines provide practical recommendations and offer adaptable advice for resource-limited settings. Importantly, they reinforce key principles such as ensuring that patients receive clear information, advising visitors on hand hygiene practises, and minimising patient transfers to reduce spread. It is crucial for all healthcare workers to be knowledgeable about MRSA, its transmission routes, and effective strategies to mitigate risk for the patients they interact with - a point emphasised by Roz et al. in their study conducted in Lebanon [21]. Ultimately, these measures emphasise the timeless message that prevention is better than cure and serve as a reminder of the crucial role we all play in safeguarding those under our care. The valuable insights and experiences shared by our colleagues further highlight the importance of continuing to invest in IPC measures, leveraging genomic technologies, and addressing global disparities in MRSA management.
